alert.note: Alert for Williamsburg (South Carolina) Issued by the National Weather Service

info.senderName: NWS Wilmington (Northeastern South Carolina and Southeastern North Carolina - Wilmington)
info.headline: Flood Warning issued August 31 at 11:37AM EDT until September 05 at 8:00AM EDT by NWS Wilmington
info.description: ...The Flood Warning is extended for the following rivers in North Carolina...South Carolina... Northeast Cape Fear River Near Burgaw affecting Pender County. Lumber River 1 SE Nichols affecting Dillon, Marion and Horry Counties. ...The Flood Warning continues for the following rivers in South Carolina...North Carolina... Great Pee Dee River At Pee Dee affecting Florence and Marion Counties. Black Creek At Quinby affecting Darlington and Florence Counties. Black River At Kingstree affecting Williamsburg County. Lumber River Near Lumberton affecting Robeson County. For the Northeast Cape Fear River...including Burgaw...Moderate flooding is forecast. For the Lumber River...including Nichols, Pembroke, Lumberton Usgs Gage, Maxton, Lumberton, Boardman...Minor flooding is forecast. For the Great Pee Dee River...including Bennettsville 10sw, Pee Dee...Minor flooding is forecast. For the Black Creek...including Black Creek Nr Hartsville, Quinby... Moderate flooding is forecast. For the Black River...including Kingstree...Minor flooding is forecast. ...FLOOD WARNING NOW IN EFFECT FROM LATE FRIDAY NIGHT TO TUESDAY MORNING... * WHAT...Minor flooding is forecast. * WHERE...Black River at Kingstree. * WHEN...From late Friday night to Tuesday morning. * IMPACTS...At 12.0 feet, Flood waters will affect low lying areas along the river especially upstream from the Highway 52 bridge. * ADDITIONAL DETAILS... - At 11:00 AM EDT Thursday the stage was 8.7 feet. - Forecast...The river is expected to rise above flood stage early Saturday morning to a crest of 12.4 feet early Saturday afternoon. It will then fall below flood stage Monday evening. - Flood stage is 12.0 feet. - http://www.weather.gov/safety/flood &&
info.instruction: Turn around, don`t drown when encountering flooded roads. Most flood deaths occur in vehicles. Additional information is available at water.weather.gov/ahps2/index.php?wfo=ilm . The next statement will be issued by late tonight.
